docs.lead_paragraph: Thirteen months after workers started picketing, a lumber company and its union have signed a contract offering the employees higher wages, back pay and improved pension and health insurance plans. Community groups, religious organizations and high school students had joined the protest against the company, Rode & Horn Lumber of 90 Waterbury Street, at Meadow Street, which supplies high-quality wood to carpenters and furniture makers.

headline.main: Accord Will Let Picket Signs Go Down and Wages Up

docs.abstract: Rode & Horn Lumber, Brooklyn company, signs contract offering striking employees higher wages, back pay and improved pension and health insurance plans; workers have been picketing for last 13 months; they are members of teamsters local 1205; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Dick Cheney's physician praised him for ''his prompt attention to his chest discomfort'' and called his approach of early intervention ''a role model for all'' (excerpts from news conference, Nov. 23). Indeed, early intervention is often a lifesaving matter. But Mr. Cheney is also fortunate to have health insurance, which 44 million other Americans lack. A study in the Archives of Internal Medicine this year showed a vast difference among those who find themselves in Mr. Cheney's straits. Of those with ''serious symptoms,'' 43 percent of the insured sought treatment and got care, while only 23 percent of those without insurance did so.

headline.main: Floridians Who Wonder: Did My Vote Count?; Cheney Has Insurance

docs.abstract: John V Walsh letter says Dick Cheney was able to seek prompt attention for his chest pains because he has health insurance, which 44 million other Americans lack

docs.lead_paragraph: The sun was not yet up in Albuquerque on the day after Thanksgiving, but already at least 300 people were lined up waiting for the doors of Toys 'R' Us to open at 6 a.m. They had come to grab morning-only deals like scooters (this year's must-have item) for $27.99, Furbys (last year's hot item) for $5 with any purchase, and whatever else they could stuff in their shopping carts. Theresa Avila, a 40-year-old mother of a 9-year-old daughter, said she was excited about getting her shopping done early and buying as much as possible.

headline.main: Either Online Or in Line, Time to Shop; Amid Mixed Forecasts, Strong Sales for a Day

docs.abstract: Holiday shopping season begins; analysts are divided about outlook for sales growth, with forecasts ranging from weak 2.5 percent to strong 8 percent; shoppers crowd stores, lured by early steep price cuts; Internet sales are expected to take bigger piece of total sales this holiday season, but failures among high-profile dot-coms weakens psychological threat posed by e-commerce; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Olivia Carillo walked to her daughters' school for the autumn ritual known as report card pickup night, when Chicago parents meet teachers and discuss their children's first round of grades. But this time, Mrs. Carillo, a 41-year-old mother of three, came away with a sobering surprise: Not only her girls, but also she and her husband would be marked by their teachers. Upon seeing the Chicago public school system's new Parental Involvement Report Card, Mrs. Carillo said, ''I was a little bit scared.'' Some days got so busy she barely remembered to ask her children about homework, much less check it. Occasionally, they showed up late for school. The Carillos always pushed their daughters to work hard. Now, they wondered, what would their own report cards say?

headline.main: Report Cards Are Due, Only This Time for Parents

docs.abstract: Parents of children in some 30 public schools in Chicago will be given report cards with letter grades on their, the parents', performance in 14 areas, from whether notes explain any absences to whether parents ask children about their day at school; some parents are insulted by the idea, but others have warmed to it; parents with poor track records can expect a home visit every 10 weeks from representatives the school system has trained to drop in; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Maria de Jesus Viana may have saved only a dollar, but the discovery she made could eventually be worth much, much more. When Ms. Viana went to the doctor recently complaining of shortness of breath, her physician prescribed the asthma medicine salbutamol sulfate. What happened next was something that had never happened to her, or millions of Brazilians like her, before.

headline.main: Explosion of Generics About to Occur in Brazil

docs.abstract: Generic drugs are beginning to catch on in Brazil, where brand-name medicines have long held sway; nine generics are planned under new joint venture between Teva of Israel, largest generic manufacturer in the world, and Brazil's Laboratorios Biosintetica; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the classes and the cafeterias, it looks like campus life as usual. But in the offices of Adelphi University, books and supplies are not being ordered, paid for or delivered on time. Since support staff members went on strike in September, students have been having difficulty making appointments with their advisers as the time for choosing next term's classes approaches. And some staff members are worrying that the university may be set back in its effort to recover from a crisis three years ago in which its leaders were fired. A strike by about 150 secretaries, mailroom workers and technicians at this college on Long Island is wearing through its 11th week, and the clerical workers picketing here are not the only ones feeling its effects.

headline.main: In Week 11, Adelphi Strike Takes Its Toll On University

docs.abstract: Striking clerical workers at Adelphi University in Garden City, NY, are in 11th week on picket line, leaving procedures in turmoil; union is asking for five-year contract with wage increases up to 4.5 percent each year, as well as health benefits and improved pension plan; staff members are concerned that university may be set back in efforts to recover from crisis three years ago in which its leaders were fired; photo (M)
